thread.title: What's it like to cruise Australia and New Zealand?
thread.title_full: What's it like to cruise Australia and New Zealand?

title: What's it like to cruise Australia and New Zealand?
text:
For a U.S. resident, traveling to Australia literally means flying to the other end of the world. But that hasn't stopped U.S. travelers from often naming Australia as their top bucket-list destination. Gordon Bell, Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen The Great Barrier Reef stretches over more than 1,300 miles along Australia's east coast. It is a coral reef system made up of about 3,000 separate reefs. Hamilton Island Fullscreen Snorkeling is one of many ways to see the reef. The corals are colorful, and there are hundreds of types of fish, turtles and manta rays. Darren Jew, Tourism Australia Fullscreen Another way to see the reef is by helicopter ride. Hamilton Island Fullscreen The highlight of the ride is flying over Heart Reef. Tanya Puntti, Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen The Yarra Valley is home to a thriving wine industry that benefits from its cooler climate. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Yering Station is the oldest vineyard in the region. Its first planting was in 1838. Roberto Seba, Tourism Australia / Time Out Australia Fullscreen Balgownie Estate has been producing wines since 1969. Mostly known for reds, Balgownie is now expanding its collection of whites and sparkling wines. Roberto Seba, Tourism Australia / Time Out Australia Fullscreen Think of Sydney, and you'll most likely picture the iconic Sydney Opera House. mingis, Getty Images Fullscreen Sydney's BridgeClimb offers what is probably the best view of the harbor. BridgeClimb Sydney Fullscreen BridgeClimb Express is the fastest way to get to the summit. Climbers ascend through the heart of the Bridge. If you have more time, you can navigate your way to the top through the outer rim. BridgeClimb Sydney Fullscreen The legendary Bondi Icebergs swimming club was founded in 1929. Getting into the club is quite a feat as members have to abide by strict swimming schedules, even during the winter. Andrew Wallace, Tourism Australia Fullscreen Bronte Beach is a stop on the nearly 4-mile Bondi to Coogee walk. lovleah, Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Watsons Bay, an eastern suburb of Sydney, offers some of the best views of the city. Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen The beach at Coogee. Getty Images/iStockphoto 3 CONNECT 34 TWEET 3 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Cruises combining the "bucket list" destinations of Australia and New Zealand allow you easily to explore world-class cities, see spectacular scenery, learn about indigenous culture, spot exotic birds and watch kangaroos hopping off into the wilderness. The high season for Down Under cruises is October to March, which is spring and summer on that side of the equator. There are many itinerary variations, but one-way, 12-day or more sailings between Auckland and Sydney give you a taste of both of these big countries.
Pre- and post-cruise tours allow time to explore Auckland and its nearby islands, Sydney and its islands and nearby mountains and such places as the Great Barrier Reef. Here are some of our favorite experiences.
Birds: On New Zealand's Otago Peninsula, you can catch sight of feathered giants at the Royal Albatross Centre and glimpse rare yellow-eyed penguins. Near the Art Deco town of Napier, a visit to Cape Kidnappers allows time to walk among a whole colony of gannets. In Australia, listen for the "laughing" call of the Kookaburra, and near Melbourne, watch penguins on their nightly parade on Phillip Island.
Fjords: Writer Rudyard Kipling called the spectacular glacier-carved fjord known as Milford Sound "the eighth wonder of the world." Cut through snow-covered mountains, the scene there is little changed since being discovered by Maoris more than 1,000 years ago. There's a catch to exploration in this part of New Zealand's southwest coast, though. If you're lucky the water will be as flat and beautiful as ice. But if you hit a storm, the trip to the Fjordlands National Park can be rough and you may or may not get to the views you've come to see.
The Hobbit and Lord of the Rings: Locations for the Peter Jackson movies are the focus of shore excursions including to the Hobbiton movie set, from Tauranga, New Zealand. But the ethereal scenery on New Zealand's North and South islands – rugged mountains, lakes and lush green valleys – will remind you of the movies whether you visit the actual sets or not.
Tasmania: Hobart is a hidden jewel on the itinerary. Ocean-view roads lead to wineries, scenic outlooks, nature centers where you can learn about the Tasmanian Devil (not just a comic book creation but a real carnivorous marsupial) and the Port Arthur penal colony, a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The Great Barrier Reef: Exploring the world's largest coral reef system is an opportunity not to be missed. Choose a cruise itinerary that includes Cairns or plan to fly up from Sydney. If you don't snorkel or dive, there are glass-bottom boat and submarine tours that show off the coral and some of the more than 1,500 fish species, sea turtles, whales and other marine creatures that hang out here.
Sydney BridgeClimb: Sydney and Auckland are both cosmopolitan cities with a wealth of attractions. But for bragging rights, nothing tops a climb on the Sydney Harbour Bridge. After a training session you put on a special suit and harness and hit the ladders and catwalks to reach the structure's upper arch, some 400 feet above the water. It is safe but spectacular.
Wild creatures: You may find opportunity at zoos or nature centers to hug a koala. Kangaroos, wallabies, wombats, crocodiles and platypus may be among other sights, including in the wild. Just figuring out which wild and unusual animals are displayed in black outline on yellow roadway warning signs is a fun challenge – the creatures are far from the deer shapes you're used to seeing at home.
Geysers and Maori culture: On a fascinating excursion from Tauranga to Rotorua, New Zealand, you can see hot lava and steam spurt from the earth, witness an exuberant display of Haka dancing and combat skills and dine on such traditional dishes as pig cooked underground.
Local experiences onboard: Cruise lines including Royal Caribbean, Princess, Holland America and Celebrity Cruises cater on the route to not just Americans but also Australian and Kiwi passengers. Regionally focused adaptations mean you can sample local beer and wine, try vegemite and meat pies and sample such dishes as New Zealand Salmon Wellington, green-lipped mussels and New Zealand lamb. Local performers will come onboard – including hysterically naughty comedians – and the nightlife may be more lively than usual.
Active excursions: Surfing on sand dunes, rafting whitewater rapids in a rainforest, bungee jumping, kayaking to a geothermal bath and swimming through a glowworm cave are among the many adrenaline-rush adventures available en-route.
You've done bike tours, but this one from Newcastle, in New South Wales, is on an all-terrain quad bike and takes you through the largest sand dunes in the Southern Hemisphere. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen North of Brisbane, wrap your arms around a koala at the Australia Zoo, founded by the late "Crocodile Hunter" Steve Irwin and his family. Terri Irwin is pictured with one of koalas from Australia Zoo in Beerwah, Queensland, Australia. Charles Knight, AP Fullscreen Or take a river cruise from Brisbane to The Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary, home to more than 130 of the sleepy marsupials. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen Mrs Laureen Harper of Canada is pictured with a koala at the Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary, as part of the G20 Leaders' Spouse programme on November 15, 2014 in Brisbane, Australia. Getty Images Fullscreen From Cairns, you head to the Tablelands and take a plunge into a natural pool at Josephine Falls or Millaa-Millaa Falls. Then, at Wooroonooran National Park, explore high in the treetops on a manmade canopy walkway. Keep an eye out for members of the resident population of platypus. Getty Images Fullscreen Treetop walk 2Another treetop tour is offered in Western Australia at Walpole-Nornalup National Park, where you walk 130 feet above the ground viewing giant karri and tingle trees. Pajara Thongjaj, Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Red Tingle trees are unique to the Walpole area. Rene Drouyer, Getty Images Fullscreen From Cairns, your destination is the Barron River, for a rainforest rafting experience. The river flows through a UNESCO World Heritage-listed Wet Tropics zone, the scenery worth more than a passing glance. Getty Images Fullscreen While a few other cities now have a bridge-climbing experience, the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb is the original and most famous. BridgeClimb Sydney Fullscreen After a training session you put on a special suit and harness and hit the ladders and catwalks to reach the structure's upper arch, some 400 feet above the water. BridgeClimb Sydney Fullscreen Visitors scale ladders, stairs and catwalks as they’re led to the top of the iconic Sydney Harbour Bridge in Australia. BridgeClimb Sydney Fullscreen See the comical spectacle of adorable little waddling penguins in the hundreds and sometimes thousands heading from the sea back to their burrows for the evening. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen The event takes place on a beach on Phillip Island, near Melbourne. It's in the dark, lights from the visitor center helping you see the action. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen On the Jumping Crocodiles excursions, inspired by the success of Paul Hogan ("Crocodile Dundee"), you head from Darwin, capital of the Northern Territory, to the Adelaide River Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen The Adelaide River is a hangout spot for the region's huge saltwater reptiles. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen Seeing the crocodiles jump and snap their jaws you'll be glad you're watching from a safe distance. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen Estuarine crocodiles, known locally as "salties," are also on view on tours to Queensland's Proserpine River. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen In Southwest Australia, you can tour deep inside Ngilgi Cave, just outside the town of Yallingup. State-of-the-art lighting at Ngilgi Cave illuminates hidden marvels and highlights remarkable stalactities, helictities, shawls, columns and more. Geographe Bay Tourism Association Fullscreen Uncover a treasure trove of spectacular cave formations at every turn as you explore Ngilgi Cave. Hear stories of legendary battles, romantic escapades and close encounters from your expert guide. Geographe Bay Tourism Association Fullscreen Leave the boardwalks behind and descend 45 metres below the earth's surface on an adrenalin-pumping Ngilgi Cave Adventure Tour. Geographe Bay Tourism Association Fullscreen More adventurous spelunkers can crawl an underground labyrinth as deep as 147 feet below the earth's surface. Geographe Bay Tourism Association Fullscreen ours have been offered here since 1900, with lighted boardwalks leading through various chambers. Geographe Bay Tourism Association Fullscreen The Wardandi and Bibbulman people of the Busselton, Dunsborough and Margaret River areas of Australia's South West have walked this ancient land for almost 50,000 years. Geographe Bay Tourism Association Fullscreen Dromedary (one-hump) camels from the Canary Islands arrived in the Kimberley region around 1840. They served as a means of transportation for early settlers. Since being replaced by cars they have pretty much been left to roam, and today there are some 400,000 camels in the wild. Celebrity Cruises Fullscreen Your opportunity to ride is on Cable Beach, a stretch of white-sand beach along the turquoise water of the Indian Ocean, with red sandstone cliffs as the backdrop. Celebrity Cruises Fullscreen They don't call it the "Great Barrier Reef" for nothing. Exploring the world's largest coral reef system is a "Bucket List" opportunity, not to be missed. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen If you don't snorkel or dive there are glass-bottom boat and submarine tours that show off the coral and some of the more than 1,500 fish species, sea turtles, whales and other marine creatures that hang out here. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen If you are willing to get in the warm water you'll find yourself immersed in a colorful world, communing with creatures that include fascinating, prehistoric-looking giant clams.
